title-group.article-title: The Natural Rate of Unemployment Hypothesis and the Evolution of Regional Disparities in Spanish Unemployment

author-notes.corresp: Roberto Bande is in the Department of Economics, University of Santiago de Compostela GAME-IDEGA, Avenida do Burgo s/n, Santiago de Compostela, A Coruna, 15782, Spain. Email: roberto.bande@usc.es.
Marika Karanassou is in the School of Economics and Finance, Queen Mary, University of London, London, UK. Email: m.karanassou@qmul.ac.uk.

abstract.p: On both theoretical and empirical grounds, this paper demonstrates that the natural rate of unemployment (NRU) cannot explain the evolution of regional unemployment disparities in Spain. The analytical framework of the chain reaction theory (CRT) of unemployment argues that an interactive labour market system, rather than a single-equation model, is better equipped to accommodate unemployment dynamics and that unemployment does not gravitate towards its NRU due to the interplay of frictions and growth. Two groups of high and low unemployment regions are identified with substantial disparities that remain stable in their composition through time. Evaluating the natural rates for each group of regions, it is confirmed that regional unemployment disparities cannot be attributed to disparities in the NRUs. Thus, instead of focusing on the determinants of the NRU, an appraisal of the contributions of the exogenous variables to the unemployment trajectory should take hold in policy-making.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The existence and persistence of large regional unemployment disparities has been a recurrent theme in the literature (see inter alia, OECD, 2005; Taylor and Bradley, 1997; Decresin and Fatás, 1995; Blanchard and Katz, 1992). Many views have been put forward to explain why regional unemployment rates can diverge for long periods within countries. The prevailing idea seems to be that disparities reflect regional differences in the long-run equilibrium of the unemployment rate—namely, differences in the natural rates of unemployment (NRU).

According to Marston (1985), regional unemployment disparities may reflect either an equilibrium outcome, due to differences in the regional natural rates of unemployment (determined by demand, supply and institutional variables which evolve steadily through time) or a disequilibrium outcome that results from differences in the regional labour markets’ adjustment to common shocks, giving rise to a polarisation effect. Much of the research has tried to disentangle these views and to provide explanations in favour of the equilibrium or the disequilibrium approaches (see Pekhonen and Tervo, 1998; and López-Bazo et al., 2005; for instance).

The NRU approach to explaining unemployment disparities relies heavily on two presumptions, not always stated clearly. First, is the very existence of a natural rate. Second, is that the NRU is a reference point—i.e. the natural rate acts as an attractor around which unemployment evolves. In this case, the design of labour market policies is straightforward: policies should aim at reducing the regional natural rates, mainly through supply-side policies, given that in the standard literature demand-side innovations do not exert significant effects on the natural rate.

In this paper, we contribute to the literature by approaching the regional unemployment issue from a different perspective, that of the chain reaction theory (CRT) of unemployment. Within a labour market system of equations, the CRT views the evolution of unemployment as the dynamic adjustment to shocks, where ‘shocks’ refer to the changes in the exogenous variables of the model.1 Since different regions may be exposed to different types of shocks and experience different lagged adjustment processes, the CRT framework encompasses both the equilibrium and disequilibrium interpretations of regional disparities.

While the NRU has become the incumbent way of thinking, various strands of the macro-labour literature have opined that employment, wage setting and labour force participation decisions (all characterised by significant lags) are important dimensions of the unemployment problem. Notably, Elhorst (2003) concludes that the standard approach of estimating reduced form unemployment rate equations is poorly equipped to determine the factors responsible for regional unemployment disparities, since these disparities are the outcome of simultaneous labour demand, wage setting and labour supply relations.

The unemployment predictions of CRT multi-equation systems are in stark contrast to those of the NRU models. We argue that the chain reaction theory reconciles the role of trended variables in labour market models with the trendless path of the unemployment rate. In other words, growing variables (like capital stock) can be included alongside the usual stationary ones (like tax rates) as determinants of the unemployment rate. We further demonstrate that the interplay of lagged adjustment processes and growth factors, what we call frictional growth, is a key difference between the CRT and NRU methodologies that leads to opposing views regarding market conditions: while the NRU presumes that the short and long run are compartmentalised, frictional growth implies that they are interdependent in CRT models. Put differently, it is fallacious to view unemployment as gravitating towards the natural rate.

Consequently, the two approaches offer a dramatically different identification of the driving forces of unemployment: whereas the CRT recognises the major influence of growth factors (such as capital accumulation), the NRU restricts its attention to wage-push determinants (such as benefits) or supply-side shocks. As far as policy is concerned, while the NRU focuses on the determinants of the natural unemployment rate (basically labour market institutions in the tradition of Blanchard and Wolfers, 2000; and Nickell et al., 2005), the CRT focuses on the determinants of actual unemployment rates and the contribution of the exogenous variables to its evolution.

In this respect, Bande and Karanassou (2009) showed that investment was the main factor contributing to the downward trend of unemployment in the Spanish regions during the boom 1985–91 period and to the rise in unemployment during the recession years in the first half of the 1990s. Interestingly, we view these CRT results as complementing the study of López-Bazo and Motellón (2011) who investigate regional unemployment disparities in Spain using micro data for two groups of regions (high and low unemployment respectively). Estimating a probit model that captures the probability of being unemployed as the cumulative normal distribution function of endowments and the behavioural responses to these characteristics, they point out that the significance and the size of the intercept indicate the strong influence of the macroeconomic conditions in each group of regions.

Despite the popularity of the NRU approach, the number of papers providing estimates of the natural rate at the regional level is scant. This is surprising, since many of the regional-based labour market policies are designed having the natural rate hypothesis in the background.

Using data for the US states, Partridge and Rickman (1997) estimate the differences in regional NRUs with respect to the national NRU and find strong and persistent differences in the regional NRUs due to regional amenities, crime rates, education and homeownership. Murphy and Payne (2003) estimate a somewhat different model for the US and find that changes in the national NRU are due to regional effects. These regional trends in the underlying natural rates are driven mainly by wages, education and young population. Remarkably, they find no significant effects of unionisation, unemployment benefits and industrial employment structure on regional NRUs. Miller (1987) and Johnson and Kneebone (1991), regressing regional unemployment rates in Canada on labour supply variables (which drive the natural component of unemployment) and cyclical ones, find that Canadian disparities in unemployment may well be explained by different regional NRUs.

Leaving aside the estimation of a reduced form unemployment rate equation, several authors have explored alternative NRU empirical avenues. For instance, Pehkonen and Tervo (1998) compute long-run unemployment rates for the Finnish regions and municipalities with autoregressive and moving-average models. For the regional data, they find persistent disparities, due to different NRUs, and a positive correlation between unemployment persistence and the natural rates. However, with local data this correlation weakens and the disparities are less persistent. Groenewold and Hagger (2003) estimate regional natural rates for the Australian regions through structural vector autoregressions and find that disparities are due to different regional NRUs. Nevertheless, depending on the region considered, the authors identify very different degrees of linkages between actual and natural rates.

This work, rather than estimating a single-equation NRU model, addresses regional disparities by estimating a CRT multi-equation labour market model with interactive dynamics, taking the Spanish experience as a benchmark. Spain has been characterised by high and persistent aggregate unemployment rates as well as a remarkable degree of regional variation in unemployment rate figures.2 Having derived the univariate representation of unemployment from this empirical system of equations, we evaluate the regional NRUs and find that actual unemployment does not gravitate towards its natural rate. As the NRU is no longer a reference point, its explanatory power for unemployment becomes questionable. Instead of trying to identify the determinants of an elusive NRU, an appraisal of the contributions of the exogenous variables to the unemployment trajectory (within a CRT framework) should take hold in policy-making.

Here is the structure of the paper. Section 2 presents our analytical framework and discusses the main differences between the NRU and CRT approaches. Section 3 portrays the evolution of Spanish disparities since 1980 and classifies the regions into two groups of high and low relative unemployment rates. Section 4 provides the econometric results of the labour market system for each group of regions. Section 5 evaluates the NRUs corresponding to the empirical models and shows that Spanish regional unemployment does not evolve around its natural rate. Section 6 concludes.

sec.title: 2. Natural Rate versus Chain Reaction of Unemployment
2.1 The NRU Story
sec.p: Conventional models of unemployment dynamics are commonly derived in terms of a wage–price spiral that determines the equilibrium unemployment rate in the long run, known as the natural rate of unemployment. The simplest characterisation of such a spiral involves: a wage-setting equation, where nominal wages are set as a mark-up over prices; and a price-setting (essentially an inverted labour demand) equation, where prices are set as a mark-up over (nominal) wages. While both mark-ups are a function of the unemployment rate (as a proxy of demand-side pressures), the wage mark-up also depends on wage-push variables (like minimum wages, unemployment benefits and union power). Since price setting is the real wage that firms are willing to concede, the price mark-up is referred to as the ‘feasible real wage’. On the other hand, wage-setting reflects the real wage that workers would like to obtain; the wage mark-up is thus known as the ‘target real wage’. This system of equations, coined the ‘battle of the mark-ups’, can only be solved in terms of unemployment. The resulting reduced-form unemployment rate equation culminates to the NRU, the policy implications of which are, mainly, that generous unemployment benefits, increased union power and low wage flexibility lead to a higher natural rate of unemployment. Peculiarly, in the NRU framework, growing variables (such as labour productivity, capital stock and working-age population) play no role in determining the long-run unemployment rate.

As already mentioned, despite the popularity of the NRU approach, several authors (for example, Elhorst, 2003) have emphasised that regional unemployment disparities are the outcome of simultaneous employment, real wage and labour force equations, rather than a single reduced-form unemployment rate equation. Furthermore, much of the macro-labour research has established that a significant dimension of the unemployment problem is the lag structure of the labour market. Along these lines, the CRT uses dynamic multi-equation systems to determine the factors driving unemployment.

sec.title: 2.2 CRT Analytics
sec.p: In a framework of dynamic multi-equation models, the CRT views the movements in unemployment as the outcome of the responses of the endogenous variables to macro-labour ‘shocks’ (i.e. changes in the exogenous variables). The ‘chain reaction’ epithet highlights the intertemporal responses of unemployment to shocks.

The responses are propelled by interacting lagged adjustment processes—namely, the lags of the endogenous variables in the system that are well documented in the literature.3 For example, firms’ current employment decisions commonly depend on their past employment on account of costs of hiring, training and firing; current wage decisions depend on past wages due to staggered wage setting; labour force participation decisions depend on the past labour force on account of costs of entering and exiting from the labour force.4

In turn, the network of lagged adjustments is activated by spillovers, occurring when endogenous variables have explanatory power in other equations of the system. Note that ‘simultaneity’, an issue inherent in CRT models, is being referred to as ‘spillovers’ in order to emphasise the plethora of feedback mechanisms in the model and to flag their importance for evaluating the driving forces of unemployment.

sec.title: 2.3 Long-run, Natural Rate and Frictional Growth
sec.p: In what follows, we demonstrate the implications of the CRT for the long-run unemployment rate and the role of frictional growth in its determination. Recall that frictional growth arises from the interplay between lagged adjustment processes and growing variables in multi-equation models.

Equation (17) provides useful insights with respect to the trajectory of the unemployment rate in the long run. Specifically, the long-run value (uLR) around which unemployment evolves reduces to the NRU only when frictional growth is zero. In other words, the NRU serves as an attractor of the actual unemployment rate either when the exogenous variables do not grow in the long run—i.e. λ=0,6 or when labour demand and supply share a common dynamic structure—i.e. α1=α2. Given that neither of these two conditions seems plausible, disregarding the phenomenon of frictional growth in the evolution of unemployment implies that the NRU testament may lead to erroneous policy responses.

With the chain reaction framework of analysis in the background, we carry on to investigate the large and persistent regional unemployment disparities in Spain. We first examine the magnitude and dynamics of these disparities and then challenge the conventional NRU view by estimating a CRT labour market model and assessing the role played by frictional growth in the long-run unemployment rates.

sec.title: 3. Regional Unemployment Disparities in Spain
sec.p: Spain is one of the European countries more severely affected by high and persistent unemployment rates. Moreover, the regional dimension of the problem is striking, with marked regional disparities that do not vanish through time. Many explanations for this feature have been put forward (see Bande et al., 2009; López-Bazo et al., 2002; Jimeno and Bentolila, 1998; and Villaverde and Maza, 2002, for different approaches), but the most widely used approach is based on underlying equilibrium (or natural) unemployment rate differences across regions. Still, a common theme in the current literature on the topic is that regional unemployment in Spain is regionally clustered, with strong and persistent differences across groups of regions (see inter alia, López-Bazo and Motellón, 2011; Bande and Karanassou, 2009; Bande et al., 2008; and López-Bazo et al., 2005). All these papers find that Spanish regions can be categorised into high and low unemployment groups that have remained fairly stable through time. In this section, we offer a brief account of this classification, which will provide the basis of our empirical approach in section 4.

First, we analyse the regional unemployment distribution in Spain by estimating kernel density functions of the relative unemployment rates.7 In particular, the kernel density estimator employed here follows the work of Quah (1997), Overman and Puga (2002) and López-Bazo et al. (2002, 2005).8 Using regional unemployment data from the Spanish Labour Force Survey (EPA), which is the source for official unemployment figures in Spain, we estimate the kernel density at different points in time and evaluate the shape of the distribution.9 Results are portrayed in Figure 1.

caption.p: Kernel density functions: relative unemployment rates.
Notes: all densities have been estimated with a Gaussian kernel. For the bandwidth, the Silverman option has been chosen.

sec.p: Figure 1 (panel a) plots the estimated distribution in 1980. We clearly observe that regional unemployment rates were almost normally distributed around the aggregate unemployment rate (as the mean/mode of relative unemployment rate is close to unity), but a two-mode distribution is starting to appear. By 1990, a two-regime distribution has been well established (Figure 1, b and c). The kernel density in 1990 (2000) is clearly characterised by two modes: a low unemployment regime located around 0.8 (0.9) and a high unemployment one around 1.6 (1.8). In fact, the plots demonstrate that the high economic growth experienced by the Spanish economy since 1995 was associated with an intensified divergence of regional unemployment rates. The abrupt arrival of the Great Recession slowed the divergent evolution of regional unemployment rates. The surprising increase in unemployment—by 2011, Spain recorded around 5 million unemployed workers and an aggregate unemployment rate of 21 per cent—brought about a drastic reduction in disparities. Figure 1 (panel e) shows that the distribution of regional unemployment in 2010 was located around the Spanish national rate, even though two modes can still be slightly discerned (at 0.7 and 1.2 respectively). Actually, a Silverman multimodal test does not allow the rejection of the null of a two-mode regime (results are available upon request).

In view of this kernel density evidence, we group the Spanish regions into a high unemployment and a low unemployment group according to the evolution of their unemployment rates through time. The former comprises the regions of Andalucia, Asturias, Canarias, Cantabria, Castilla–La Mancha, Castilla y León, Extremadura, Galicia, Murcia and Comunidad Valenciana, while the latter consists of the regions of Aragon, Illes Balears, Cataluña, Comunidad de Madrid, Navarra, Pais Vasco and La Rioja. These groups are similar to those reported by Bande et al. (2008), Bande and Karanassou (2009) and López-Bazo and Motellón (2011).

Figure 2 (panel a) plots the absolute unemployment rates of each group, while Figure 2 (panel b) shows that the contrast in their evolution through time is reflected by the dramatic increase in the disparities between the relative unemployment rates of the two groups. Observe that there has been a sustained increase (decrease) in the relative unemployment rate of the group of high (low) unemployment since 1983, the only exception being the 1992–94 period when it briefly decreased (increased).

caption.p: Unemployment rates and relative unemployment rates.

sec.p: The existence of a high and low unemployment group of regions with distinct economic performances forms the basis of the empirical approach in the next section, where we estimate idiosyncratic regional labour market models for each group and show that there are substantial differences between the two labour markets.

sec.title: 4. Econometric Methodology
sec.p: Working with two panels of regions, one panel of the 10 high unemployment rate regions and another one of the seven low unemployment rate regions, we estimate an expanded version of the structural chain reaction model presented in section 2. In particular, our empirical labour demand, wage setting and labour force equations are characterised by a variety of lagged adjustment processes and feedback mechanisms.

Estimation of this structural system (18) involves the selection of the exogenous variables and the number of lags to be included in each of its equations. As these are mainly judgemental decisions, the methodology of structural modelling relies heavily on discretion. Nevertheless, the advantage of the structural modelling approach is the economic intuition and plausibility that accompany each of the estimated equations.11 In the estimated models, the actual number of lags in the endogenous and exogenous variables may differ across equations and groups of regions, since our empirical methodology follows the ‘general to specific’ tradition for each equation, whereby we start with a fairly general model and reduce it to a more parsimonious specification on the basis of standard model selection criteria (such as the Akaike information criterion).

Acknowledging the need for a large number of observations for a robust investigation of the evolution of regional unemployment disparities through time, we opt for pooled estimation.12 Specifically, we use a fixed-effects (FE) model comprising the system (18) and a vector of one-way error component disturbances eit

where, vit~iid(0,σν2) with Cov(eit,ejt)=0, for i≠j. The vector of scalars μi represents the effects that are specific to the ith region and are assumed to remain constant over time. In other words, the FE model assumes that slope coefficients and variances are identical across regions and only intercepts are allowed to vary.

Due to data limitations, our dataset covers the 1980–2000 period13 and is obtained from: Datastream; the BD-MORES dataset, elaborated by the Dirección General de Análisis y Programación Presupuestaria (Ministry of Economy) and the University of Valencia; and, the Spanish Labour Force data, elaborated by the Spanish Statistics Institute (INE). FE estimation enables us to use 210 and 147 observations for the high and low unemployment rate panels respectively. The main advantage of the BD-MORES dataset is that it provides homogeneous regional accounting-type data for Spanish regions for a sufficiently large number of years. Also, in addition to the regional value added and its components, it provides regional gross value added deflators which allow the computation of variables in real terms. Finally, the reported capital stock series are coherent with the rest of the dataset, which is one of the few available regional sources providing such data for such long-period samples. sec.p: The multi-equation system (18) consists of: a labour demand equation, describing the equilibrium employment (nit); a wage-setting equation, describing real wage (wit) determination; and, a labour supply equation, describing the equilibrium size of the labour force (lit). In addition, our model contains the definition of the unemployment rate (definition): uit=lit−nit. According to (18), the regional unemployment rate is determined by local conditions measured by the regional exogenous variables xit (such as capital stock); and nation-wide variables zt (such as oil prices) which are common to all regions. In contrast, the models in Blanchard and Katz (1992) and Decresin and Fatás (1995) emphasise regional dynamics as opposed to national dynamics, analysing exclusively the effects of regional specific shocks.

We construct a panel for each group of high and low unemployment regions, as defined in the previous section along the lines of the structural system (18). Our model does not account for any labour or firm mobility between the high and low unemployment groups of regions.14 This is in line with the results for Europe by Decresin and Fatás (1995), but is in contrast to the findings of Blanchard and Katz (1992) who assume perfect mobility of workers and firms between regions and find that this assumption is valid for the behaviour of US workers and firms.

Dynamic panel data and non-stationary panel time-series models have attracted a lot of attention over the past several years. As a result, the study of the asymptotics of macro panels with large N (number of units, for example, countries or regions) and large T (length of the time-series) has become the focus of panel data econometrics.15 Thus, we have carried on with unit root tests to decide whether or not to use stationary panel data estimation techniques. The results of the KPSS unit root to aggregate national variables show that we cannot reject the null hypothesis of (trend) stationarity for the national series. Moreover, the Maddala and Wu (1999) panel unit root test strongly rejects the null of a unit root in all of the regional variables.16 Bearing in mind that some findings of the research on regional and local labour markets have signified the existence of spatial dependence in the unemployment rates (see inter alia, Patacchini and Zenou, 2007; Overman and Puga, 2002; and Molho, 1995) and acknowledging that spatial correlation is associated with biased regression results (Anselin, 1988), we also tested for the existence of spatial dependence in our data through the Moran’s I statistic. Results (not reported for brevity but available upon request) could not reject the null of randomness in the spatial distribution of the regional variables in our model at conventional levels of confidence. In the light of these results, we conclude that spatial dependence does not present a problem in our estimations. Therefore, all of this evidence indicates that it is appropriate to apply stationary panel data estimation techniques.17

sec.p: Regarding labour demand, the lagged employment terms are associated with the employment adjustment process. Employment depends negatively on the real wage and positively on both the level and growth rate of capital stock. The oil price and direct taxes (as a ratio to GDP) have a negative impact on labour demand.
In the wage setting equation, real wage depends negatively on unemployment and positively on productivity and benefits. The lag of real wage reflects the adjustment process due to wage staggering.

Finally, concerning labour supply, the autoregressive coefficient signifies the influence of the labour force adjustment process and the size of the labour force depends positively on the working-age population and negatively on real wages.20 Also note that, in each equation of each group, all variables are statistically significant at conventional levels.

It is worthwhile to observe that, in these estimations, the unemployment rate is influenced by the size of the capital stock both in the short run and long run. This is a key characteristic of the CRT, which, unlike the influential NRU, asserts that trended factors (such as capital stock and working-age population) influence the trajectory of the unemployment rate, a non-trended variable.21
Figure 3 shows that the fitted unemployment rate generated by our system tracks the trajectory of the actual unemployment rate very closely.

sec.title: 5. Actual and Natural Rates of Unemployment
sec.p: On the basis of the empirical results in Tables 2 and 3, this section attempts to evaluate the natural rates of unemployment in each group of regions and compare their evolution through time.

In this respect, we compute the unemployment rate according to equation (12)—i.e. the unemployment rate that would prevail had the dynamics fully worked themselves out at any time t, given the permanent values of the exogenous variables in the model. To achieve this we consider the steady states of the equations in the estimated panels of Tables 2 and 3 (i.e. we set the lag operators equal to unity) and we identify the permanent components of the exogenous variables by estimating kernel density functions, a procedure proposed by Karanassou et al. (2008). Note that this method is an alternative to extracting the permanent components of a time-series using the Hodrick–Prescott filter, Kalman filter, etc.

Plotting the kernel density distribution of each stationary exogenous variable is indicative of the number and status of the different regimes present in the series. A unimodal density characterises a unique regime, which is regarded as permanent in our sample period and its mean is equal to the value of the mode. A bimodal kernel density describes the case of two regimes divided by a ‘valley point’: the boundaries of the two regimes depend on whether observations lie to the left or to the right of this data point.

When a series exhibits two regimes, we compare its kernel density with the actual series. If a variable starts in a regime (say A) in the beginning of the sample and then moves to another regime (say B), we need to observe whether this change is permanent or transitory. If the variable returns to regime A, then regime B is transitory and A is permanent, measured by the corresponding mode value. However, if the variable remains at regime B, then the latter is regarded as another permanent regime. For a non-stationary variable (for instance, capital stock), we compute the kernel density function of its growth rate, identify the regime of this growth variable and then compute the associated level of its permanent component series.22

Having identified the permanent and temporary regimes, we substitute the permanent components series of the exogenous variables in the equations of Tables 2 and 3, set the lagged values equal to the current ones (i.e. the lag operator L=1 ) and solve the resulting models for the unemployment rate to obtain the natural rate of each region. The NRU of each group is computed by summing up the regional natural levels of employment and labour force, and then subtracting these summations according to the unemployment definition (4).
The results are pictured in Figure 4, where panels (a) and (b) plot the actual and natural rates of the high and low unemployment groups of regions respectively.

caption.p: Actual and natural rates of unemployment in high and low unemployment regions.

sec.p: The information in Figure 4 provides some interesting insights regarding the evolution of the NRU and the actual rates. Starting with the first half of the 1980s, actual unemployment deviated markedly (almost 4–8 percentage points, pp) from its natural rate. More importantly, note that, while the strong economic recovery of the second half of the 1980s led to a substantial reduction in the actual unemployment rates (about 4 pp in the high unemployment group and 12 pp in the low unemployment regions), this was not accompanied by a decrease in the natural rates. In contrast, the NRUs continued increasing, reaching their highest levels during the recession of the early 1990s and then slightly decreasing by 2000. As the actual unemployment rate had experienced a large fall of more than 10 pp from its peak in the mid 1990s, the NRU was 11 (7) pp higher than the actual rate in the low (high) unemployment group of regions in 2000.

These results clearly show that unemployment has not evolved around its natural rate over the 1980–2000 period. Put differently, the NRU has not acted as an attractor of the regional unemployment in Spain.23

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: This paper, following the chain reaction approach, demonstrated that unemployment does not evolve around its natural rate due to the phenomenon of frictional growth. Put differently, the interplay of lagged adjustment processes and growth in labour markets implies that the NRU explanation of regional disparities is misleading.

The analysis in section 2 showed that, unlike the single-equation NRU models, the CRT multi-equation systems are characterised by a network of interacting lagged adjustment processes and include growing variables in their explanatory sets. The CRT framework views the movements in unemployment as ‘chain reactions’ (intertemporal responses) to labour market shocks (changes in the exogenous variables) and can thus capture frictional growth. Since different regions may be exposed to different types of shocks and experience different lagged adjustment processes, CRT models have a clear advantage over the NRU ones in explaining regional unemployment disparities.

The Spanish regions were classified in section 3 into two groups of high and low unemployment rates. In section 4, we estimated an augmented version of the stylised CRT model (of section 2) for each group to assess the determinants of regional unemployment in Spain during the 1980–2000 period. We then computed in section 5 the natural rates corresponding to each group of regions and showed that the deviations of actual unemployment from its natural rate are substantial throughout the sample. This finding confirms that frictional growth has been an important factor in the evolution of regional unemployment disparities.

Consequently, policies that aim at reducing disparities through the natural rates are likely to fail, since they do not take into account the interplay of dynamics and growth (like changes in investment) in the unfolding of regional unemployment. As actual unemployment does not gravitate towards its natural rate, the explanatory power of the NRU becomes questionable. In this case, we believe that an appraisal of the unemployment contributions of the exogenous variables within a CRT framework should take hold in policy-making. It can be further argued that different policies should be applied to different groups of regions, a result that casts doubts on the effectiveness of the recent policy decisions by the Spanish government to apply a common set of labour market reforms to the whole country.
